Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evolutionary mechanisms of skewed gender ratios and reproductive plasticity
Award.AbstractNarration: Roundworm infections cause several debilitating diseases in both animals and agricultural plants, yet relatively little is known about the factors that regulate either the population dynamics and/or infectivity of most parasitic or free-living nematode species. This proposal aims to uncover the mechanisms by which a specific set of closely related roundworm species regulate the ratio of males, females, and/or infective/dispersive larval forms amongst their offspring. A combination of cellular, chemical and genetic approaches will be used. Broader impacts of the proposal studies include establishing research and student training links between a primarily undergraduate institution (William & Mary) and an institution with a large proportion of minority students (UT-Arlington). In addition, these studies may ultimately lead to new avenues for controlling roundworm infections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Roundworm infections cause debilitating diseases in both animals and agricultural plants, yet relatively little is known about the factors that regulate either their population dynamics or the development of their larvae to develop into infective rather than non-infective forms.  For this project, we were studying a set of closely related roundworms (nematodes), whose populations, like those of many parasitic forms, include not only males and female but also self-fertile forms (hermaphrodites) that produce both sperm and oocytes. Within these populations, the development of hermaphrodites but not males or females is linked in an obligatory way to passage through a distinct larval stage (dauer) than is equivalent to the infective larvae of parasitic forms. Intriguingly, our chosen species, also like many parasitic forms, exhibits skewed gender ratios that can’t be explained by standard Mendelian genetics; but unlike parasitic forms, our species eat bacteria and are easy to rear under standard laboratory conditions. This proposal sought to uncover the mechanisms by which a particular nematodes (Rhabditis sp. SB347, now called Auanema rhodensis) and its near relatives regulate the ratio of males, females, and hermaphrodites amongst their offspring.

How does A. rhodensis achieve its ratio of male, females, and hermaphrodites?

1)      If females and hermaphrodites are both genetically XX, how is this decision developmentally determined? Females and hermaphrodites were known to be born with different sized gonads, but in this study, we identified molecular compounds (pheromones) that could convert female-fated larvae to develop as hermaphrodites or could be inhibited and convert hermaphrodite-fated larvae to develop as females.  

2)      At a population level, how is the species propagated? In this study, we found that populations expands primarily through male/female crosses and self-fertilization in hermaphrodites. In an unusual twist, crosses between XX females and X males yield exclusively XX feminine progeny (rather than a 50:50 mix of females and males) whereas X males are produced by self-fertilizing XX hermaphrodites which produce about 10% male progeny early in their broods.

3)      What cellular mechanisms enable A. rhodensis males to produce exclusively X-bearing sperm? Our analysis of how the structural (cytoskeletal) elements reorganize during sperm development in a variety of nematode species revealed unappreciated similarities to processes in both dividing and differentiating cells. In A. rhodensis, sperm production employs standard cellular mechanisms, but in the tiny spermatocytes, a bipolar process that normally generates two sperm and a cellular waste bag called a residual body, becomes unipolar, generating one sperm and a residual body containing the other complement of genetic material.

4)      How do A. rhodensis hermaphrodites achieve self-fertility? In an unexpected finding, we discovered that A. rhodensis hermaphrodites produce sperm in a fundamentally different way than the well-studied model nematode Caenorhabiditis elegans. Whereas the gonad of C. elegans hermaphrodites produces a small number of sperm before switching over to the exclusive production of oocytes, A. rhodensis hermaphrodite produce sperm and oocytes in a same gonad at the same time. We also discovered that one reason they can do this is that their sperm production involves a population of dividing cells that are intermediates between germline stem cells and spermatocytes (the cells that will directly divide to form sperm). Although such cells are considered a “universal” feature of sperm production, our study is the first to report such cells in nematodes.

The broader impacts of this study are two-fold. In terms of training the next generation of young scientists, these studies have provided in-depth research training in the Shakes’ lab for two masters’ students and ten undergraduates (including 2 Hispanics and 1 African American) . Importantly, their training included the opportunity to present their work at scientific conferences. Two also participated in a lab-exchange; one student from the Pires daSilva lab spent the summer in my lab and one of my students spent a semester in the Pires daSilva lab. Aspects of the project were also incorporated into my upper division teaching lab, thus expanding the experience of investigative research to an additional 30 students. At another level, these ground level studies have the potential to impact diverse areas of the life sciences. A. rhodensis is increasingly being recognized as a lab-cultivatable, “model parasite” whose analysis may reveal new ways to suppress pathogenic nematodes of both humans and agriculturally important species. Our finding that A. rhodensis sperm production is more similar to that of other organisms, opens new possibilities for studying this aspect of reproductive biology in a nematode model. Lastly, our continuing studies on how segregation of the X-chromosome is regulated in this species to achieve non-standard sex ratios is interesting not only in the broader context of basic genetics, but it also promised to yield new clues regarding the abnormal chromosome segregation processes that are associated with human birth defects and increased cancer malignancy.
